TITLE: Defining a Flyte Workflow with Task
DESCRIPTION: This code defines a Flyte workflow and a task using the `@task` and `@workflow` decorators. The `say_hello` task takes a name as input and returns a greeting. The `hello_world_wf` workflow calls the `say_hello` task with a default name and returns the result. The `if __name__ == "__main__"` block demonstrates how to run the workflow locally.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/quickstart_guide.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from flytekit import task, workflow


@task
def say_hello(name: str) -> str:
    return f"Hello, {name}!"


@workflow
def hello_world_wf(name: str = 'world') -> str:
    res = say_hello(name=name)
    return res


if __name__ == "__main__":
    print(f"Running wf() {hello_world_wf(name='passengers')}")
```

----------------------------------------

DESCRIPTION: This code defines a simple Flyte task that returns the string 'Hello, World!'. It demonstrates how to use the @task decorator to create a Flyte task from a Python function.

LANGUAGE: python

```

TITLE: Defining a Basic Flyte Task in Python
DESCRIPTION: Creates a simple Flyte task for calculating the mean of a list of floating-point values. The task is decorated with @task and includes type annotations for input and output parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_fundamentals/tasks_workflows_and_launch_plans.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from typing import List
from flytekit import task

@task
def mean(values: List[float]) -> float:
    return sum(values) / len(values)
```

TITLE: Creating Basic Flyte Hello World Workflow in Python
DESCRIPTION: A simple Flyte workflow that demonstrates basic task and workflow definitions using decorators to create a hello world example.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/environment_setup.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

```
from flytekit import task, workflow

def say_hello() -> str:

@workflow

TITLE: Configuring Task Retries for Error Resilience
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to implement a task with retry capabilities for handling potential errors, specifying a maximum of 3 retries and using a recoverable exception for demonstration.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_fundamentals/optimizing_tasks.md#2025-04-16_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import random
from flytekit import task

@task(retries=3)
def compute_mean(data: List[float]) -> float:
    if random() < 0.05:
        raise FlyteRecoverableException("Something bad happened ðŸ”¥")
    return sum(data) / len(data)
```

TITLE: FlyteRemote Execution Inspection
DESCRIPTION: Python code demonstrating how to use FlyteRemote to fetch and inspect execution details, including accessing inputs, outputs, and node executions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/development_lifecycle/inspecting_executions.md#2025-04-16_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from flytekit.remote import FlyteRemote

# FlyteRemote object is the main entrypoint to API
remote = FlyteRemote(
    config=Config.for_endpoint(endpoint="flyte.example.net"),
    default_project="flytesnacks",
    default_domain="development",
)

execution = remote.fetch_execution(
    name="fb22e306a0d91e1c6000", project="flytesnacks", domain="development"
)

input_keys = execution.inputs.keys()
output_keys = execution.outputs.keys()

# The inputs and outputs correspond to the top-level execution or the workflow itself.
# To fetch a specific output, say, a model file:
model_file = execution.outputs["model_file"]
with open(model_file) as f:
    ...

# You can use FlyteRemote.sync() to sync the entity object's state with the remote state during the execution run.
synced_execution = remote.sync(execution, sync_nodes=True)
node_keys = synced_execution.node_executions.keys()

# node_executions will fetch all the underlying node executions recursively.
# To fetch output of a specific node execution:
node_execution_output = synced_execution.node_executions["n1"].outputs["model_file"]
```

TITLE: Defining Standard Deviation and Scaling Tasks in Python
DESCRIPTION: Implements two additional Flyte tasks: one to calculate standard deviation of a list of values and another to perform standard scaling (mean centering and dividing by standard deviation).
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_fundamentals/tasks_workflows_and_launch_plans.md#2025-04-16_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from math import sqrt
from flytekit import workflow


@task
def standard_deviation(values: List[float], mu: float) -> float:
    variance = sum([(x - mu) ** 2 for x in values])
    return sqrt(variance)

@task
def standard_scale(values: List[float], mu: float, sigma: float) -> List[float]:
    return [(x - mu) / sigma for x in values]
```

)

TITLE: Using Task Output in Complex Flyte Conditional
DESCRIPTION: This example shows a more complex workflow that uses the output of a task to determine which calculation to perform in a conditional statement.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/conditionals.md#2025-04-16_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def coin_toss(seed: int) -> str:
    random.seed(seed)
    return random.choice(["heads", "tails"])

@workflow
def consume_task_output(radius: float, seed: int) -> float:
    coin_result = coin_toss(seed=seed)
    return (
        conditional("coin_toss_condition")
        .if_(coin_result == "heads")
        .then(calculate_circle_circumference(radius=radius))
        .else_()
        .then(calculate_circle_area(radius=radius))
    )
```

TITLE: Programmatic Task Execution with FlyteRemote
DESCRIPTION: Python code demonstrating how to execute a task programmatically using FlyteRemote API, including configuration, task fetching, registration, execution, and result inspection
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/development_lifecycle/running_tasks.md#2025-04-16_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from flytekit.remote import FlyteRemote
from flytekit.configuration import Config, SerializationSettings

# FlyteRemote object is the main entrypoint to API
remote = FlyteRemote(
    config=Config.for_endpoint(endpoint="flyte.example.net"),
    default_project="flytesnacks",
    default_domain="development",
)

# Get Task
flyte_task = remote.fetch_task(name="workflows.example.generate_normal_df", version="v1")

flyte_task = remote.register_task(
    entity=flyte_task,
    serialization_settings=SerializationSettings(image_config=None),
    version="v2",
)

# Run Task
execution = remote.execute(
     flyte_task, inputs={"n": 200, "mean": 0.0, "sigma": 1.0}, execution_name="task-execution", wait=True
)

# Or use execution_name_prefix to avoid repeated execution names
execution = remote.execute(
     flyte_task, inputs={"n": 200, "mean": 0.0, "sigma": 1.0}, execution_name_prefix="flyte", wait=True
)

# Inspecting execution
# The 'inputs' and 'outputs' correspond to the task execution.
input_keys = execution.inputs.keys()
output_keys = execution.outputs.keys()
```

TITLE: Consuming Conditional Output in Flyte Workflow
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to consume the output returned by a conditional statement in a Flyte workflow.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/conditionals.md#2025-04-16_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def calculate_circle_properties(radius: float) -> float:
    return (
        conditional("if_fraction")
        .if_((radius >= 0) & (radius <= 1))
        .then(calculate_circle_circumference(radius=radius))
        .else_()
        .then(calculate_circle_area(radius=radius))
    )

@task
def print_outputs(t1_output: float) -> float:
    print(f"Output of first task: {t1_output}")
    return t1_output

@workflow
def shape_properties_accept_conditional_output(radius: float) -> float:
    result = calculate_circle_properties(radius=radius)
    return print_outputs(t1_output=result)
```

TITLE: Configuring Task Plugins in YAML
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the configuration of task plugins within a YAML file for Flyte. It includes enabling multiple plugins such as container, sidecar, k8s-array, and dask, and setting them as defaults for specific task types. The configuration is used to override default values during deployment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/deployment/plugins/k8s/index.rst#2025-04-16_snippet_30

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
tasks:
  task-plugins:
    enabled-plugins:
      - container
      - sidecar
      - k8s-array
      - dask
    default-for-task-types:
      - container: container
      - container_array: k8s-array
      - dask: dask
```

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
configmap:
  enabled_plugins:
    tasks:
      task-plugins:
        enabled-plugins:
          - container
          - sidecar
          - k8s-array
          - dask
        default-for-task-types:
          container: container
          sidecar: sidecar
          container_array: k8s-array
          dask: dask
```

TITLE: Implementing Basic Regression Line Calculation Subworkflow in Python
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates calculation of slope and intercept in one workflow and using it as a subworkflow in another to compute y-values. Shows basic subworkflow pattern with two workflows: slope_intercept_wf and regression_line_wf.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/subworkflows.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import typing
from flytekit import task, workflow

@task
def slope(x: typing.List[int], y: typing.List[int]) -> float:
    x_mean = sum(x) / len(x)
    y_mean = sum(y) / len(y)
    num = sum((x[i] - x_mean) * (y[i] - y_mean) for i in range(len(x)))
    den = sum((x[i] - x_mean) ** 2 for i in range(len(x)))
    return num / den

@task
def intercept(x: typing.List[int], y: typing.List[int], m: float) -> float:
    return sum(y) / len(y) - m * sum(x) / len(x)

@workflow
def slope_intercept_wf(x: typing.List[int], y: typing.List[int]) -> typing.Tuple[float, float]:
    m = slope(x=x, y=y)
    b = intercept(x=x, y=y, m=m)
    return m, b

@task
def compute_y(x: typing.List[int], m: float, b: float) -> typing.List[float]:
    return [m * xi + b for xi in x]

@workflow
def regression_line_wf(x: typing.List[int], y: typing.List[int]) -> typing.List[float]:
    m, b = slope_intercept_wf(x=x, y=y)
    y_pred = compute_y(x=x, m=m, b=b)
    return y_pred
```

TITLE: Embedding Flyte Launch Plans in Workflows
DESCRIPTION: This code shows how to embed a launch plan within a workflow function using the '@workflow' decorator. The 'workflow_with_launchplan' function demonstrates computing data using given parameters, then executing the 'standard_scale_launch_plan' with the generated data. This practice increases modularity and separation of concerns by managing workflows as distinct, callable entities within Flyte.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_fundamentals/tasks_workflows_and_launch_plans.md#2025-04-16_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: Python
CODE:
```
@workflow
def workflow_with_launchplan(num_samples: int, seed: int) -> List[float]:
    data = generate_data(num_samples=num_samples, seed=seed)
    return standard_scale_launch_plan(values=data)

workflow_with_launchplan(num_samples=10, seed=3)
```

   name="flytekit",  # default docker image name.
   base_image="ghcr.io/flyteorg/flytekit:py3.11-1.10.2",  # the base image that flytekit will use to build your image.
   packages=["pandas"],  # python packages to install.

   python_version="3.11"  # Optional if python is installed in the base image.
)

TITLE: Using Boolean Workflow Inputs in Flyte Conditional
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to use a boolean input directly in a conditional statement within a Flyte workflow.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/conditionals.md#2025-04-16_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@workflow
def boolean_input_wf(boolean_input: bool) -> str:
    return (
        conditional("test")
        .if_(boolean_input.is_true())
        .then(print_value(value="boolean_input is True"))
        .else_()
        .then(print_value(value="boolean_input is False"))
    )
```

TITLE: Complete Workflow State Transitions
DESCRIPTION: Detailed mermaid flowchart showing all possible workflow state transitions including error handling and abort scenarios.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/concepts/main_concepts/state_machine.rst#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: mermaid
CODE:
```
flowchart TD
     Queued -->|On system errors more than threshold| Aborted
     Queued --> Ready
     Ready--> |Write inputs to workflow| Running
     Running--> |On system error| Running
     Running--> |On all Nodes Success| Succeeding
     Succeeding--> |On successful event send to Admin| Succeeded
     Succeeding--> |On system error| Succeeding
     Ready--> |On precondition failure| Failing
     Running--> |On any Node Failure| Failing
     Ready--> |On user initiated abort| Aborting
     Running--> |On user initiated abort| Aborting
     Succeeding--> |On user initiated abort| Aborting
     Failing--> |If Failure node exists| HandleFailureNode
     Failing--> |On user initiated abort| Aborting
     HandleFailureNode--> |On completing failure node| Failed
     HandleFailureNode--> |On user initiated abort| Aborting
     Failing--> |On successful send of Failure node| Failed
     Aborting--> |On successful event send to Admin| Aborted
```

TITLE: Executing Workflows Using FlyteRemote in Python
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use FlyteRemote to execute Flyte workflows remotely. Shows configuration setup, workflow fetching, and execution with different naming options. Includes both basic execution and execution with prefix-based naming.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/development_lifecycle/running_workflows.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

from flytekit.remote import FlyteRemote
from flytekit.configuration import Config

# FlyteRemote object is the main entrypoint to API
remote = FlyteRemote(
    config=Config.for_endpoint(endpoint="flyte.example.net"),
    default_project="flytesnacks",
    default_domain="development",
)

# Fetch workflow
flyte_workflow = remote.fetch_workflow(name="workflows.example.wf", version="v1")

# Execute
execution = remote.execute(
    flyte_workflow, inputs={"mean": 1}, execution_name="workflow-execution", wait=True
)

# Or use execution_name_prefix to avoid repeated execution names
execution = remote.execute(
    flyte_workflow, inputs={"mean": 1}, execution_name_prefix="flyte", wait=True
)
```

TITLE: Conditional Approval Flow in Flyte
DESCRIPTION: Implements a complex workflow combining approval nodes with conditionals to handle both approved and rejected scenarios.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/waiting_for_external_inputs.md#2025-04-16_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def invalid_report(report: str, reason: str) -> str:
    return f"INVALID REPORT ({reason}):\n{report}"

@workflow
def conditional_wf(data: typing.List[float]) -> str:
    """A workflow that creates a report and conditionally processes it based on approval."""
    report = create_report(data=data)
    approved = approve(
        "review-passes",
        report,
        help="Review the report and approve if it looks good",
    )
    disapprove_reason = wait_for_input(
        "review-fails-reason",
        timeout=timedelta(hours=1),
        expected_type=str,
        default="Report looks invalid",
        help="Provide a reason for disapproving the report",
    )
    return ( 
        conditional("review_passed")
        .if_(approved.is_true())
        .then(reporting_wf(data=data))
        .else_(invalid_report(report=report, reason=disapprove_reason))
    )
```

TITLE: Implementing Map Tasks for Parallelization
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use map_task to parallelize workloads by partitioning data and processing it concurrently, with a workflow that splits data into chunks, processes them in parallel, and combines the results.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_fundamentals/optimizing_tasks.md#2025-04-16_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import math
from typing import Tuple

from flytekit import map_task


@task
def sum_and_length(data: List[float]) -> List[float]:
    """Return the sum and length of a dataset of numbers."""
    return [sum(data), float(len(data))]


@task
def prepare_partitions(data: List[float], n_partitions: int) -> List[List[float]]:
    """Create partitions from the full dataset."""
    size = math.ceil(len(data) / n_partitions)
    return [data[size * i: size * (i + 1)] for i in range(n_partitions)]

@task
def reduce(results: List[List[float]]) -> float:
    """Combine results from the map task."""
    total, length = 0.0, 0.0
    for sub_total, sub_length in results:
        total += sub_total
        length += sub_length
    return total / length


@workflow
def parallelized_compute_mean(data: List[float], n_partitions: int = 10) -> float:
    """An embarrassingly parallel implementation to compute the mean from data."""
    partitioned_data = prepare_partitions(data=data, n_partitions=n_partitions)

    # use map_task to apply the sum_and_length task to the partitions
    results = map_task(sum_and_length)(data=partitioned_data)
    return reduce(results=results)


parallelized_compute_mean(data=[float(x) for x in range(10_000)])
```

TITLE: Implementing NumPy Decoder for Structured Datasets in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code defines a NumpyDecodingHandler class that extends StructuredDatasetDecoder to convert parquet files to numpy.ndarray objects. It implements the decode method that reads the parquet file and returns its content as a NumPy array.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/data_types_and_io/structureddataset.md#2025-04-16_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class NumpyDecodingHandler(StructuredDatasetDecoder[np.ndarray]):
    """
    Implements decoders from Parquet to numpy ndarrays.
    """

    def decode(
        self,
        ctx: FlyteContext,
        flyte_value: StructuredDataset,
        current_task_metadata: WorkflowExecutionParameters,
    ) -> np.ndarray:
        """
        Converts parquet file to numpy array
        :param ctx: FlyteContext
        :param flyte_value: StructuredDataset
        :param current_task_metadata: WorkflowExecutionParameters
        :return: numpy array
        """
        local_dir = ctx.file_access.get_random_local_directory()
        ctx.file_access.get_data(flyte_value.uri, local_dir, is_multipart=True)
        path = os.path.join(local_dir, "000000")
        df = pd.read_parquet(path)
        return df.to_numpy()
```

TITLE: Defining a Flyte Task for Slope Calculation in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code defines a Flyte task that computes the slope of a regression line. It demonstrates how to use the @task decorator and type annotations for inputs and outputs.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/basics/tasks.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def slope(x: List[int], y: List[int]) -> float:
    if len(x) != len(y):
        raise ValueError("Lists x and y must have the same length")
    n = len(x)
    x_mean = sum(x) / n
    y_mean = sum(y) / n
    numerator = sum((x[i] - x_mean) * (y[i] - y_mean) for i in range(n))
    denominator = sum((x[i] - x_mean) ** 2 for i in range(n))
    return numerator / denominator
```

TITLE: Dynamic Character Counter Workflow

SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/dynamic_workflows.md#2025-04-16_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@dynamic
def count_characters(s1: str, s2: str) -> int:
    freq_list1 = [0] * 26
    freq_list2 = [0] * 26

    for c in s1:
        index = return_index(c=c)
        freq_list1 = update_list(freq_list=freq_list1, index=index)

    for c in s2:
        index = return_index(c=c)
        freq_list2 = update_list(freq_list=freq_list2, index=index)

    count = derive_count(freq_list1=freq_list1, freq_list2=freq_list2)
    return count
```

TITLE: Implementing PCA Plot Task with Deck
DESCRIPTION: Task implementation that creates a PCA plot using Flyte Decks with Markdown and Plotly visualizations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/development_lifecycle/decks.md#2025-04-16_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task(enable_deck=True, container_image=custom_image, requests=Resources(cpu="1", mem="1Gi"))
def pca_plot():
    from sklearn.datasets import load_iris
    from sklearn.decomposition import PCA
    import plotly.express as px

    iris = load_iris()
    X = pd.DataFrame(iris.data, columns=["sepal length", "sepal width", "petal length", "petal width"])
    y = pd.DataFrame(iris.target, columns=["species"])

    pca = PCA(n_components=2)
    components = pca.fit_transform(X)
    fig = px.scatter(
        components,
        x=0,
        y=1,
        color=y["species"],
        title="Flyte Deck | PCA of Iris Dataset",
        labels={"0": "First Principal Component", "1": "Second Principal Component"},
    )

    md = renderer.MarkdownRenderer()
    md.append("## Principal Component Analysis")
    md.append(
        "Principal component analysis (PCA) is a popular technique for analyzing large datasets "
        "containing a high number of dimensions/features per observation."
    )
    plotly = renderer.PlotlyRenderer()
    plotly.append(fig)
    md.append(plotly)
```

TITLE: Implementing Task Caching in Flyte
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to implement caching for expensive tasks using the cache and cache_version parameters. The example shows a task to compute the mean of a list of numbers that gets cached between workflow calls.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_fundamentals/optimizing_tasks.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from typing import List
from flytekit import task, workflow


@task(cache=True, cache_version="1")
def compute_mean(data: List[float]) -> float:
    return sum(data) / len(data)

@workflow
def wf(data: List[float]) -> float:
    return compute_mean(data=data)
```

TITLE: Implementing Sphinx-style Docstring in Flyte Workflow
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use a Sphinx-style docstring to document a Flyte workflow. It includes a brief overview, detailed explanation, and parameter/return type descriptions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/basics/documenting_workflows.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@workflow
def sphinx_docstring_wf(dataset: FlyteSchema[kw1:str, kw2:str, x:float, y:float]) -> (float, float):
    """
    Calculates slope and intercept using linear regression.

    This workflow takes a dataset as input and calculates the slope and
    intercept using linear regression. It demonstrates the use of
    Sphinx-style docstrings in Flyte workflows.

    :param dataset: Input dataset containing x and y values
    :type dataset: FlyteSchema[kw1:str, kw2:str, x:float, y:float]
    :return: Tuple containing slope and intercept
    :rtype: (float, float)
    """
    m = slope(dataset=dataset)
    b = intercept(dataset=dataset)
    return m, b
```

TITLE: Complete Reference Task Implementation Example
DESCRIPTION: A comprehensive example showing reference task implementation in Flyte. It includes both the reference task declaration and a workflow that uses it. The example demonstrates referencing a task from the same project using a registration version macro.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/productionizing/reference_tasks.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from flytekit import reference_task, workflow
from flytekit.types.file import FlyteFile


@reference_task(
    project="flytesnacks",
    domain="development",
    name="core.flyte_basics.files.normalize_columns",
    version="{{ registration.version }}",
)
def normalize_columns(
    csv_url: FlyteFile, column_names: list[str], columns_to_normalize: list[str]
) -> FlyteFile:
    """Reference to a core task that normalizes columns in a CSV file"""
    ...


@workflow
def reference_task_wf(
    csv_url: FlyteFile, column_names: list[str], columns_to_normalize: list[str]
) -> FlyteFile:
    """Normalizes column values from a CSV file."""
    return normalize_columns(
        csv_url=csv_url,
        column_names=column_names,
        columns_to_normalize=columns_to_normalize,
    )


if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Reference tasks cannot be run locally. You can test a workflow that uses a reference task
    # only by mocking out the reference task.
    # This means reference tasks are mostly useful when executing on the Flyte cluster.
    pass
```

TITLE: Creating a Python Decorator for Flyte Tasks
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a custom Python decorator that executes code before and after a Flyte task. This approach allows extending task behavior without modifying the core task code.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_fundamentals/extending_flyte.md#2025-04-16_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from functools import partial, wraps

def decorator(fn):

    @wraps(fn)
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        print("do something before")
        out = fn(*args, **kwargs)
        print("do something after")
        return out

    return wrapper
```

TITLE: Streaming CSV File Processing Using FlyteFile in Python
DESCRIPTION: This task demonstrates streaming support for FlyteFile, allowing efficient processing of remote files without full download. It removes specified columns from a CSV file and writes the result to a new file.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/data_types_and_io/flytefile.md#2025-04-16_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def remove_columns(input_file: FlyteFile, columns_to_remove: typing.List[str]) -> FlyteFile:
    with input_file.open("r") as f:
        reader = csv.DictReader(f)
        fieldnames = [col for col in reader.fieldnames if col not in columns_to_remove]
        output_file = StringIO()
        writer = csv.DictWriter(output_file, fieldnames=fieldnames)
        writer.writeheader()
        for row in reader:
            writer.writerow({k: row[k] for k in fieldnames})
    output_file.seek(0)
    return FlyteFile(output_file.getvalue())
```

TITLE: Handling Failure Scenarios in Flyte Workflow
DESCRIPTION: This workflow demonstrates a failure scenario where attempting to access out-of-range indices or non-existent keys results in workflow failure. It uses WorkflowFailurePolicy to continue execution after errors.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/data_types_and_io/accessing_attributes.md#2025-04-16_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from flytekit import WorkflowFailurePolicy


@task
def failed_task() -> (list[str], dict[str, str], Fruit):
    return ["apple", "banana"], {"fruit": "banana"}, Fruit(name="banana")


@workflow(
    # The workflow remains unaffected if one of the nodes encounters an error, as long as other executable nodes are still available
    failure_policy=WorkflowFailurePolicy.FAIL_AFTER_EXECUTABLE_NODES_COMPLETE
)
def failed_workflow():
    fruits_list, fruit_dict, fruit_instance = failed_task()
    print_message(message=fruits_list[100])  # Accessing an index that doesn't exist
    print_message(message=fruit_dict["fruits"])  # Accessing a non-existent key
    print_message(message=fruit_instance.fruit)  # Accessing a non-existent param
```

TITLE: Merge Sort Implementation
DESCRIPTION: Implementation of merge sort algorithm using dynamic workflows to demonstrate recursion
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/dynamic_workflows.md#2025-04-16_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def merge_sort(numbers: List[int], numbers_count: int) -> List[int]:
    if numbers_count <= 1:
        return numbers

    return merge_sort_remotely(numbers=numbers, numbers_count=numbers_count)

@workflow
def merge_sort_wf(numbers: List[int], numbers_count: int) -> List[int]:
    return merge_sort(numbers=numbers, numbers_count=numbers_count)

@dynamic
def merge_sort_remotely(numbers: List[int], numbers_count: int) -> List[int]:
    if numbers_count <= 1:
        return numbers

    m = numbers_count // 2
    left = numbers[:m]
    right = numbers[m:]

    # Call static version to call dynamic version
    left_sorted = merge_sort_wf(numbers=left, numbers_count=len(left))
    right_sorted = merge_sort_wf(numbers=right, numbers_count=len(right))

    return merge(left=left_sorted, right=right_sorted)

@task
def merge(left: List[int], right: List[int]) -> List[int]:
    result = []
    i = j = 0

    while i < len(left) and j < len(right):
        if left[i] < right[j]:
            result.append(left[i])
            i += 1
        else:
            result.append(right[j])
            j += 1

    result.extend(left[i:])
    result.extend(right[j:])
    return result
```

TITLE: Advanced Eager Workflow with Multiple Conditions
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to implement complex conditional logic in eager workflows using Python's native control flow and task outputs.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/eager_workflows.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def gt_100(x: int) -> bool:
    return x > 100

@eager
async def eager_workflow_with_conditionals(x: int) -> int:
    out = await add_one(x=x)
    
    if out < 0:
        return -1
    elif await gt_100(x=out):
        return await double(x=out)
    else:
        return out
```

TITLE: Implementing Google-style Docstring in Flyte Workflow
DESCRIPTION: This snippet illustrates how to use a Google-style docstring to document a Flyte workflow. It includes a one-line summary, detailed description, and parameter/return descriptions with types.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/basics/documenting_workflows.md#2025-04-16_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@workflow
def google_docstring_wf(dataset: FlyteSchema[kw1:str, kw2:str, x:float, y:float]) -> (float, float):
    """Calculates slope and intercept using linear regression.

    This workflow takes a dataset as input and calculates the slope and
    intercept using linear regression. It demonstrates the use of
    Google-style docstrings in Flyte workflows.

    Args:
        dataset (FlyteSchema[kw1:str, kw2:str, x:float, y:float]): Input dataset containing x and y values

    Returns:
        tuple: Tuple containing slope (float) and intercept (float)
    """
    m = slope(dataset=dataset)
    b = intercept(dataset=dataset)
    return m, b
```

TITLE: Controlling Memoization Behavior with Annotated Types
DESCRIPTION: Example of using typing.Annotated to control caching behavior for non-Flyte offloaded objects like pandas dataframes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/development_lifecycle/caching.md#2025-04-16_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import pandas as pd
from flytekit import task, workflow
from flytekit.types.schema import FlyteSchema
from flytekit.core.annotation import HashMethod

@task
def foo() -> typing.Annotated[pd.DataFrame, HashMethod(lambda df: df.size)]:
    return pd.DataFrame({"column1": [1, 2], "column2": [3, 4]})

@task(cache=True, cache_version="1.0")
def bar(
    df: typing.Annotated[pd.DataFrame, HashMethod(lambda df: df.size)]
) -> pd.DataFrame:
    return df[df["column1"] > 1]

@workflow
def wf() -> pd.DataFrame:
    return bar(df=foo())
```

TITLE: Implementing a Sync OpenAI Agent in Python
DESCRIPTION: Example implementation of a sync agent for OpenAI that extends SyncAgentBase with a do method to handle immediate request/response interactions with the OpenAI API.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_agents/developing_agents.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from typing import Optional
from flytekit import FlyteContextManager
from flytekit.core.type_engine import TypeEngine
from flyteidl.core.execution_pb2 import TaskExecution
from flytekit.models.literals import LiteralMap
from flytekit.models.task import TaskTemplate
from flytekit.extend.backend.base_agent import SyncAgentBase, AgentRegistry, Resource


class OpenAIAgent(SyncAgentBase):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__(task_type_name="openai")

    def do(self, task_template: TaskTemplate, inputs: Optional[LiteralMap], **kwargs) -> Resource:
        # Convert the literal map to python value.
        ctx = FlyteContextManager.current_context()
        python_inputs = TypeEngine.literal_map_to_kwargs(ctx, inputs, literal_types=task_template.interface.inputs)
        response = ask_chatgpt_question(python_inputs)
        return Resource(phase=TaskExecution.SUCCEEDED, outputs={"o0": response})

AgentRegistry.register(OpenAIAgent())
```

TITLE: Implementing Sleep Node in Flyte Workflow
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a workflow that pauses execution for a specified duration using the sleep node. The workflow adds one to a number after sleeping for 10 seconds.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/waiting_for_external_inputs.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def add_one(x: int) -> int:
    return x + 1

@workflow
def sleep_wf(x: int = 42) -> int:
    """A workflow that sleeps before computing."""
    sleeping = sleep(10)
    result = add_one(x=x)
    sleeping >> result
    return result
```

TITLE: Passing PyTorch Tensors and Modules in Flyte Tasks
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use PyTorch tensors and modules as inputs and outputs in Flyte tasks. This snippet shows the creation of a simple neural network, training it, and passing the model and data between tasks.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/data_types_and_io/pytorch_type.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import torch
from flytekit import task, workflow
from flytekit.types.pytorch import PyTorchModule, PyTorchTensor

@task
def create_model() -> PyTorchModule:
    model = torch.nn.Sequential(
        torch.nn.Linear(2, 4),
        torch.nn.ReLU(),
        torch.nn.Linear(4, 1),
    )
    return model

@task
def train_model(model: PyTorchModule, data: PyTorchTensor) -> PyTorchModule:
    criterion = torch.nn.MSELoss()
    optimizer = torch.optim.SGD(model.parameters(), lr=0.01)

    for _ in range(100):
        y_pred = model(data)
        loss = criterion(y_pred, torch.ones_like(y_pred))
        optimizer.zero_grad()
        loss.backward()
        optimizer.step()

    return model

@task
def predict(model: PyTorchModule, data: PyTorchTensor) -> PyTorchTensor:
    return model(data)

@workflow
def pytorch_training_wf(data: PyTorchTensor) -> PyTorchTensor:
    model = create_model()
    trained_model = train_model(model=model, data=data)
    return predict(model=trained_model, data=data)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    data = torch.randn(10, 2)
    print(pytorch_training_wf(data=data))
```

DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to use is_container() to conditionally import modules based on the ImageSpec environment, optimizing module loading time and dependency installation.

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from flytekit import ImageSpec, task
import pandas as pd

pandas_image_spec = ImageSpec(
  packages=["pandas"],
  registry="ghcr.io/flyteorg",
)

tensorflow_image_spec = ImageSpec(
  packages=["tensorflow", "pandas"],
  registry="ghcr.io/flyteorg",
)

# Return if and only if the task is using the image built from tensorflow_image_spec.
if tensorflow_image_spec.is_container(): 
  import tensorflow as tf

@task(container_image=pandas_image_spec)
def task1() -> pd.DataFrame:
  return pd.DataFrame({"Name": ["Tom", "Joseph"], "Age": [1, 22]})


@task(container_image=tensorflow_image_spec)
def task2() -> int:
  num_gpus = len(tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU'))
  print("Num GPUs Available: ", num_gpus)
  return num_gpus

TITLE: Flyte Types Integration with Pydantic BaseModel
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates using Flyte-specific types like StructuredDataset, FlyteFile, and FlyteDirectory within Pydantic BaseModel.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/data_types_and_io/pydantic_basemodel.md#2025-04-16_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def return_complex_types() -> Datum2:
    df = pd.DataFrame({"x": [1, 2], "y": [3, 4]})
    Path("test.txt").write_text("hello world")
    Path("test_dir/test.txt").parent.mkdir(exist_ok=True)
    Path("test_dir/test.txt").write_text("hello world")
    return Datum2(
        x=1,
        y=2,
        z="hello",
        metadata={"hello": "world"},
        sd=StructuredDataset(dataframe=df),
        ff=FlyteFile(path="test.txt"),
        fd=FlyteDirectory(path="test_dir"),
    )


@task
def consume_complex_types(d: Datum2) -> str:
    print(d.sd.open(pd.DataFrame).all())
    print(d.ff.download())
    print(d.fd.download())
    assert d.x == 1
    assert d.y == 2
    assert d.z == "hello"
    assert d.metadata["hello"] == "world"
    return "success"
```

TITLE: Chaining Tasks in Flyte using Python
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to chain tasks in Flyte using the '>>' operator. It defines three tasks (t0, t1, t2) and chains them in a workflow.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/chaining_flyte_entities.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import time

from flytekit import task, workflow


@task
def t0():
    print("Running t0")
    time.sleep(5)


@task
def t1():
    print("Running t1")
    time.sleep(5)


@task
def t2():
    print("Running t2")
    time.sleep(5)


@workflow
def chain_tasks_wf():
    t0() >> t1() >> t2()
```

TITLE: Using Task Output in Flyte Conditional

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def random_bool() -> bool:
    return random.choice([True, False])

@task
def print_value(value: str):
    print(value)

@workflow
def boolean_wf() -> str:
    random_value = random_bool()
    return (
        conditional("test")
        .if_(random_value.is_true())
        .then(print_value(value="True"))
        .else_()
        .then(print_value(value="False"))
    )
```

TITLE: Implementing Checkpointing Task in Flyte
DESCRIPTION: This task demonstrates how to use checkpointing in Flyte. It iterates for a specified number of times, checkpoints its state, and recovers from simulated failures. The task uses the Checkpoint API to save and restore state.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/intratask_checkpoints.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task(retries=3)
def use_checkpoint(n_iterations: int) -> FlyteDirectory:
    cp = Checkpoint()
    if cp.exists():
        starting_iteration = cp.read()
        print(f"Resuming from iteration: {starting_iteration}")
    else:
        starting_iteration = 0
    for i in range(starting_iteration, n_iterations):
        cp.write(i)
        if i == 3 and not cp.exists():
            print("Simulating a failure")
            raise FlyteRecoverableException("Simulated failure")
    return cp.get()
```

@task
def double(x: int) -> int:
    return x * 2

@eager
async def simple_eager_workflow(x: int) -> int:
    out = await add_one(x=x)
    if out < 0:
        return -1
    return await double(x=out)

class CoffeeType(Enum):
    ESPRESSO = "espresso"
    LATTE = "latte"
    CAPPUCCINO = "cappuccino"


@task
def make_coffee(coffee_type: CoffeeType) -> Tuple[str, CoffeeType]:
    """Make a cup of coffee based on the provided type. Barista interprets enums and makes coffee.

    :param coffee_type: Type of coffee to make
    :return: Tuple of message and coffee type
    """
    # The coffee_type will be automatically converted to enum by the system.
    # The value will be constrained to one of the valid values.
    if coffee_type == CoffeeType.ESPRESSO:
        message = "Making Espresso...â˜•ï¸"
    elif coffee_type == CoffeeType.LATTE:
        message = "Making Latte...ðŸ¥›â˜•ï¸"
    elif coffee_type == CoffeeType.CAPPUCCINO:
        message = "Making Cappuccino...ðŸ¥›â˜•ï¸"
    else:
        # This condition will never be hit because the input is constrained to valid values
        message = "Unknown coffee type"

    return message, coffee_type

TITLE: Normalizing Columns in CSV File Using FlyteFile in Python
DESCRIPTION: This task accepts a FlyteFile containing CSV data, normalizes specified columns using z-score normalization, and outputs a new CSV file with only the normalized columns.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/data_types_and_io/flytefile.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def normalize_columns(
    csv_url: FlyteFile,
    column_names: typing.List[str],
    columns_to_normalize: typing.List[str],
    output_location: str = "",
) -> CSVFile:
    local_path = csv_url.download()
    df = pd.read_csv(local_path)

    # Calculate z-score for specified columns
    for col in columns_to_normalize:
        if col in df.columns:
            mean_val = df[col].mean()
            std_val = df[col].std()
            df[col] = (df[col] - mean_val) / std_val

    # Select only the normalized columns
    df_normalized = df[columns_to_normalize]

    # Write the normalized data to a new CSV file
    output_file = StringIO()
    df_normalized.to_csv(output_file, index=False)
    output_file.seek(0)

    # If an output location is specified, use it; otherwise, Flyte will generate a random path
    return CSVFile(path=output_location) if output_location else CSVFile(output_file.getvalue())
```

TITLE: Creating a Workflow Decorator for Setup-Teardown Pattern in Flyte
DESCRIPTION: This function defines a decorator that wraps a workflow function, adding setup and teardown tasks. It uses create_node to manage task execution order and ensures proper DAG construction.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/decorating_workflows.md#2025-04-16_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def setup_teardown(before: Callable, after: Callable):
    def decorator(fn):
        @wraps(fn)
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            ctx = FlyteContext.current_context()
            before_node = create_node(before)
            after_node = create_node(after)
            output = fn(*args, **kwargs)
            if ctx.compilation_state is not None:
                # Get first and last nodes
                first_node = ctx.compilation_state.nodes[1]
                last_node = ctx.compilation_state.nodes[-2]
                # Ensure proper execution order
                before_node >> first_node
                last_node >> after_node
            return output
        return wrapper
    return decorator
```

TITLE: Demonstrating Type Checking in Flyte with Buggy Implementation
DESCRIPTION: Shows how Flyte's type system catches errors when a task's implementation doesn't match its declared return type. The task returns a float but is declared to return List[float], causing a runtime error.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_fundamentals/tasks_workflows_and_launch_plans.md#2025-04-16_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def buggy_standard_scale(values: List[float], mu: float, sigma: float) -> float:
    """
    ðŸž The implementation and output type of this task is incorrect! It should
    be List[float] instead of a sum of all the scaled values.
    """
    return sum([(x - mu) / sigma for x in values])

@workflow
def buggy_standard_scale_workflow(values: List[float]) -> List[float]:
    mu = mean(values=values)
    sigma = standard_deviation(values=values, mu=mu)
    return buggy_standard_scale(values=values, mu=mu, sigma=sigma)

try:
    buggy_standard_scale_workflow(values=[float(i) for i in range(1, 11)])
except Exception as e:
    print(e)
```

TITLE: Implementing an Async BigQuery Agent in Python
DESCRIPTION: Example implementation of an async agent for BigQuery that extends AsyncAgentBase with create, get, and delete methods to manage BigQuery jobs.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_agents/developing_agents.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from typing import Optional
from dataclasses import dataclass
from flytekit.models.literals import LiteralMap
from flytekit.models.task import TaskTemplate
from flytekit.extend.backend.base_agent import AsyncAgentBase, AgentRegistry, Resource, ResourceMeta


@dataclass
class BigQueryMetadata(ResourceMeta):
    """
    This is the metadata for the job. For example, the id of the job.
    """
    job_id: str

class BigQueryAgent(AsyncAgentBase):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__(task_type_name="bigquery", metadata_type=BigQueryMetadata)

    def create(
        self,
        task_template: TaskTemplate,
        inputs: Optional[LiteralMap] = None,
        **kwargs,
    ) -> BigQueryMetadata:
        job_id = submit_bigquery_job(inputs)
        return BigQueryMetadata(job_id=job_id)

    def get(self, resource_meta: BigQueryMetadata, **kwargs) -> Resource:
        phase, outputs = get_job_status(resource_meta.job_id)
        return Resource(phase=phase, outputs=outputs)

    def delete(self, resource_meta: BigQueryMetadata, **kwargs):
        cancel_bigquery_job(resource_meta.job_id)

# To register the bigquery agent
AgentRegistry.register(BigQueryAgent())
```

import typing

from flytekit import task, workflow
from sklearn.datasets import load_wine


@task(container_image="{{.images.mindmeld}}")
def t1() -> typing.Tuple[typing.List[int], typing.List[str]]:
    wine = load_wine()
    return wine.target[:5].tolist(), wine.feature_names[:5]


@task(container_image="{{.images.borebuster}}")
def t2(targets: typing.List[int], features: typing.List[str]) -> str:
    targets_str = ", ".join([str(val) for val in targets])
    features_str = ", ".join(features)
    return f"targets: [{targets_str}], features: [{features_str}]"


@workflow
def multi_images_wf() -> str:
    targets, features = t1()
    return t2(targets=targets, features=features)
```

TITLE: Implementing Output Validation Decorator for Flyte Tasks
DESCRIPTION: This function defines a decorator that verifies if the output from the decorated function is a positive number. It raises a ValueError if the condition is not met.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/decorating_tasks.md#2025-04-16_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def validate_output(min_value):
    def decorator(fn):
        @wraps(fn)
        def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
            output = fn(*args, **kwargs)
            if output < min_value:
                raise ValueError(f"Output {output} is less than {min_value}")
            return output
        return wrapper
    return decorator
```

TITLE: Using PyTorchCheckpoint for Model Serialization in Flyte
DESCRIPTION: Illustrates the usage of PyTorchCheckpoint for serializing and deserializing PyTorch models in Flyte. This snippet shows how to save and load model state, hyperparameters, and optimizer state using PyTorchCheckpoint.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/data_types_and_io/pytorch_type.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import torch
from dataclasses import dataclass
from flytekit import task, workflow
from flytekit.types.pytorch import PyTorchCheckpoint

@dataclass
class Hyperparameters:
    learning_rate: float
    batch_size: int

@task
def train_model(hp: Hyperparameters) -> PyTorchCheckpoint:
    model = torch.nn.Linear(10, 1)
    optimizer = torch.optim.Adam(model.parameters(), lr=hp.learning_rate)
    
    checkpoint = PyTorchCheckpoint(
        module=model,
        optimizer_state=optimizer.state_dict(),
        hyperparameters=hp,
    )
    return checkpoint

@task
def use_model(checkpoint: PyTorchCheckpoint) -> float:
    model = torch.nn.Linear(10, 1)
    model.load_state_dict(checkpoint["module_state_dict"])
    optimizer = torch.optim.Adam(model.parameters())
    optimizer.load_state_dict(checkpoint["optimizer_state"])
    hp = checkpoint["hyperparameters"]
    
    # Use the model and hyperparameters
    x = torch.randn(hp.batch_size, 10)
    y = model(x)
    return y.mean().item()

@workflow
def pytorch_checkpoint_wf(learning_rate: float, batch_size: int) -> float:
    hp = Hyperparameters(learning_rate=learning_rate, batch_size=batch_size)
    checkpoint = train_model(hp=hp)
    return use_model(checkpoint=checkpoint)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    print(pytorch_checkpoint_wf(learning_rate=0.01, batch_size=32))
```

    Calculates slope and intercept using linear regression.

    This workflow takes a dataset as input and calculates the slope and
    intercept using linear regression. It demonstrates the use of
    NumPy-style docstrings in Flyte workflows.

    Parameters
    ----------
    dataset : FlyteSchema[kw1:str, kw2:str, x:float, y:float]
        Input dataset containing x and y values

    Returns
    -------
    tuple
        Tuple containing slope (float) and intercept (float)

SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/productionizing/workflow_labels_and_annotations.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from flytekit import Labels, Annotations

@workflow
class MyWorkflow(object):
    ...

my_launch_plan = MyWorkflow.create_launch_plan(...)

my_launch_plan.execute(
    labels=Labels({"myexecutionlabel": "bar", ...}),
    annotations=Annotations({"region": "SEA", ...}),
    ...
)
```

TITLE: Defining a Workflow with Shell Tasks in Python
DESCRIPTION: This workflow combines the previously defined shell tasks and the create_entities task. It demonstrates how to chain tasks together, passing outputs from one task as inputs to another.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/basics/shell_tasks.md#2025-04-16_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@workflow
def shell_task_wf(x: str, a: int) -> (FlyteFile, FlyteFile, FlyteDirectory):
    f1, d1 = create_entities(a=a)
    f2 = t1(x=x)
    f3 = t2(a=f2)
    d2 = t3(d=d1, x=x)
    return f1, f3, d2
```

TITLE: Implementing Nested Typed Columns in Flyte StructuredDataset
DESCRIPTION: This extended example demonstrates how to work with nested field structures in StructuredDataset. It includes complex data structures with nested fields, custom encoders and decoders for these structures, and a full workflow implementation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/data_types_and_io/structureddataset.md#2025-04-16_snippet_11

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# Define nested Python typing in Flyte StructuredDataset
class NestedSchema(TypedDict):
    a: int
    b: str
    c: List[int]


class ComplexSchema(TypedDict):
    x: int
    y: str
    z: NestedSchema
    lst: List[Dict[str, int]]


@dataclass
class NestedSchemaModel:
    a: int
    b: str
    c: List[int]


@dataclass
class ComplexSchemaModel:
    x: int
    y: str
    z: NestedSchemaModel
    lst: List[Dict[str, int]]


# Register Decoder for ComplexSchemaModel
class ComplexSchemaModelDecodingHandler(StructuredDatasetDecoder[ComplexSchemaModel]):
    """
    Decoder for ComplexSchemaModel
    """

    def decode(
        self,
        ctx: FlyteContext,
        flyte_value: StructuredDataset,
        current_task_metadata: WorkflowExecutionParameters,
    ) -> ComplexSchemaModel:
        local_dir = ctx.file_access.get_random_local_directory()
        ctx.file_access.get_data(flyte_value.uri, local_dir, is_multipart=True)
        path = os.path.join(local_dir, "000000")
        df = pd.read_parquet(path)
        # Assume that there's only one record in the dataframe
        row = df.iloc[0]
        return ComplexSchemaModel(
            x=row["x"],
            y=row["y"],
            z=NestedSchemaModel(
                a=row["z.a"],
                b=row["z.b"],
                c=row["z.c"],
            ),
            lst=row["lst"],
        )


# Register Encoder for ComplexSchemaModel
class ComplexSchemaModelEncodingHandler(StructuredDatasetEncoder):
    """
    Encoder for ComplexSchemaModel
    """

    def encode(
        self,
        ctx: FlyteContext,
        structured_dataset: ComplexSchemaModel,
        structured_dataset_type: StructuredDatasetType,
        destination: Optional[str] = None,
    ) -> StructuredDataset:
        cols = {
            "x": [structured_dataset.x],
            "y": [structured_dataset.y],
            "z.a": [structured_dataset.z.a],
            "z.b": [structured_dataset.z.b],
            "z.c": [structured_dataset.z.c],
            "lst": [structured_dataset.lst],
        }
        df = pd.DataFrame(cols)

        # Get a random local directory for the file
        if destination is None:
            destination = ctx.file_access.join(
                ctx.file_access.raw_output_prefix,
                ctx.file_access.get_random_string(),
            )

        local_dir = ctx.file_access.get_random_local_directory()
        filename = os.path.join(local_dir, "000000")
        df.to_parquet(filename)
        ctx.file_access.put_data(local_dir, destination, is_multipart=True)

        schema = StructuredDatasetType.Schema(columns={})
        return StructuredDataset(uri=destination, metadata=StructuredDatasetMetadata(structured_dataset_type=structured_dataset_type, schema=schema))


class ComplexSchemaModelRenderer(TypeRenderer):
    """
    Renderer for ComplexSchemaModel
    """

    def to_html(self, obj: ComplexSchemaModel) -> str:
        return f"""<div>
            <p>x: {obj.x}</p>
            <p>y: {obj.y}</p>
            <p>z.a: {obj.z.a}</p>
            <p>z.b: {obj.z.b}</p>
            <p>z.c: {obj.z.c}</p>
            <p>lst: {obj.lst}</p>
        </div>"""


# Register the encoder, decoder and renderer
TypeEngine.register(ComplexSchemaModelRenderer(name="ComplexSchemaModel"))
StructuredDatasetTransformerEngine.register(ComplexSchemaModelEncodingHandler(), ComplexSchemaModel)
StructuredDatasetTransformerEngine.register_decoder(
    ComplexSchemaModelDecodingHandler(), ComplexSchemaModel, pandas.DataFrame, byte_format=StructuredDatasetType.PARQUET
)


@task
def generate_nested_schema() -> ComplexSchemaModel:
    return ComplexSchemaModel(
        x=1,
        y="2",
        z=NestedSchemaModel(a=3, b="4", c=[5, 6, 7]),
        lst=[{"a": 8}, {"b": 9}],
    )


@task
def consume_nested_schema(model: ComplexSchemaModel) -> ComplexSchemaModel:
    return ComplexSchemaModel(
        x=model.x + 1,
        y=model.y + "_processed",
        z=NestedSchemaModel(a=model.z.a + 1, b=model.z.b + "_processed", c=[i + 1 for i in model.z.c]),
        lst=model.lst + [{"c": 10}],
    )


@workflow
def nested_schema_wf() -> ComplexSchemaModel:
    model = generate_nested_schema()
    return consume_nested_schema(model=model)
```

TITLE: Implementing a Basic Workflow for Scheduling in Flyte
DESCRIPTION: A simple workflow that formats a given date parameter. This workflow can be scheduled to run automatically, and it can receive the scheduled kickoff time as an input parameter.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/productionizing/schedules.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import datetime

from flytekit import task, workflow


@task
def format_date(kickoff_time: datetime.datetime) -> str:
    return kickoff_time.strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S")


@workflow
def date_formatter_wf(kickoff_time: datetime.datetime) -> str:
    formatted_kickoff_time = format_date(kickoff_time=kickoff_time)
    return formatted_kickoff_time
```

TITLE: Running No-op Task in Flyte Conditional
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to use a no-op task (echo) in a conditional statement to skip execution when a condition is not met.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/conditionals.md#2025-04-16_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
echo = ShellTask(
    name="echo",
    script="echo",
)

@workflow
def noop_in_conditional(radius: float, seed: int) -> float:
    coin_result = coin_toss(seed=seed)
    return (
        conditional("coin_toss_condition")
        .if_(coin_result == "heads")
        .then(calculate_circle_circumference(radius=radius))
        .else_()
        .then(echo(text="Skipping execution"))
    )
```

TITLE: Creating Custom Coordinate Type in Python
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create a custom Flyte type called Coordinate using Python dataclasses, which includes x and y coordinates plus metadata. The class inherits from DataClassJSONMixin to enable serialization.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_fundamentals/extending_flyte.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import typing

from dataclasses import dataclass
from mashumaro.mixins.json import DataClassJSONMixin

@dataclass
class Coordinate(DataClassJSONMixin):
    """A custom type for coordinates with metadata attached."""
    x: float
    y: float
    metadata: typing.Dict[str, float]
```

TITLE: Downloading Files to FlyteDirectory in Python
DESCRIPTION: This task downloads a list of URLs pointing to CSV files and returns the folder path as a FlyteDirectory object.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/data_types_and_io/flytedirectory.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def download_files(urls: List[str]) -> FlyteDirectory:
    downloaded_directory = FlyteDirectory("downloaded_csvs")
    for idx, url in enumerate(urls):
        file_location = os.path.join(downloaded_directory.name, f"file_{idx}.csv")
        FlyteFile(url).download(file_location)
    return downloaded_directory
```

TITLE: Implementing MyDataset TypeTransformer
DESCRIPTION: Custom TypeTransformer implementation for MyDataset that handles conversion between local and remote data representations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/extending/custom_types.md#2025-04-16_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
T = TypeVar("T")

class MyDatasetTransformer(TypeTransformer[MyDataset]):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__(name="MyDataset")

    def get_literal_type(self, t: Type[T]) -> LiteralType:
        return LiteralType(simple=SimpleType.BLOB)

    def to_literal(self, ctx: FlyteContext, python_val: MyDataset, python_type: Type[MyDataset], expected: LiteralType) -> Literal:
        local_path = python_val.path
        random_dir = ctx.file_access.get_random_local_directory()
        local_path = os.path.join(random_dir, os.path.basename(local_path))
        os.makedirs(local_path, exist_ok=True)
        remote_path = ctx.file_access.get_random_remote_directory()
        ctx.file_access.put_data(local_path, remote_path, is_multipart=True)
        return Literal(scalar=Blob(uri=remote_path, metadata=BlobMetadata(type=SimpleType.BLOB)))

    def to_python_value(self, ctx: FlyteContext, lv: Literal, expected_python_type: Type[MyDataset]) -> MyDataset:
        local_path = ctx.file_access.get_random_local_directory()
        ctx.file_access.get_data(lv.scalar.uri, local_path, is_multipart=True)
        return MyDataset(local_path)
```

TITLE: GPU-Specific Pod Configuration in Kubernetes
DESCRIPTION: YAML showing the pod spec configuration for a specific GPU device on GKE. Includes nodeAffinity for GPU type selection and tolerations for scheduling on GPU-enabled nodes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/productionizing/configuring_access_to_gpus.md#2025-04-16_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
spec:
  affinity:
    nodeAffinity:
      requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:
        nodeSelectorTerms:
        - matchExpressions:
          - key: cloud.google.com/gke-accelerator
            operator: In
            values:
            - nvidia-tesla-v100
  containers:
  - resources:
      limits:
        nvidia.com/gpu: 1
  tolerations:
  - key: nvidia.com/gpu  # auto
    operator: Equal
    value: present
    effect: NoSchedule
  - key: cloud.google.com/gke-accelerator
    operator: Equal
    value: nvidia-tesla-v100
    effect: NoSchedule
```

TITLE: Implementing Nested Dynamic Workflows in Flyte
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates a three-level workflow hierarchy using dynamic workflows to process lists in parallel. Includes core workflow tasks, intermediate level dynamic workflows, and a top-level workflow orchestrator.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/nested_parallelization.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
"""\nA core workflow parallelized as six items with a chunk size of two will be structured as follows:\n\nmulti_wf -> level1 -> level2 -> core_wf -> step1 -> step2\n                             -> core_wf -> step1 -> step2\n                      level2 -> core_wf -> step1 -> step2\n                             -> core_wf -> step1 -> step2\n                      level2 -> core_wf -> step1 -> step2\n                             -> core_wf -> step1 -> step2\n"""\n\nimport typing\nfrom flytekit import task, workflow, dynamic, LaunchPlan\n\n\n@task\ndef step1(a: int) -> int:\n    return a + 1\n\n\n@task\ndef step2(a: int) -> int:\n    return a + 2\n\n\n@workflow\ndef core_wf(a: int) -> int:\n    return step2(a=step1(a=a))\n\n\ncore_wf_lp = LaunchPlan.get_or_create(core_wf)\n\n\n@dynamic\ndef level2(l: typing.List[int]) -> typing.List[int]:\n    return [core_wf_lp(a=a) for a in l]\n\n\n@task\ndef reduce(l: typing.List[typing.List[int]]) -> typing.List[int]:\n    f = []\n    for i in l:\n        f.extend(i)\n    return f\n\n\n@dynamic\ndef level1(l: typing.List[int], chunk: int) -> typing.List[int]:\n    v = []\n    for i in range(0, len(l), chunk):\n        v.append(level2(l=l[i:i + chunk]))\n    return reduce(l=v)\n\n\n@workflow\ndef multi_wf(l: typing.List[int], chunk: int) -> typing.List[int]:\n    return level1(l=l, chunk=chunk)
```

TITLE: Mixed Parallelism with Map Tasks in Flyte
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates combining dynamic workflows with map tasks for parallel processing, offering a different approach to nested parallelization with fewer layers.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/nested_parallelization.md#2025-04-16_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
"""\nA core workflow parallelized as six items with a chunk size of two will be structured as follows:\n\nmulti_wf -> level1 -> level2 -> mappable\n                             -> mappable\n                      level2 -> mappable\n                             -> mappable\n                      level2 -> mappable\n                             -> mappable\n"""\nimport typing\nfrom flytekit import task, workflow, dynamic, map_task\n\n\n@task\ndef mappable(a: int) -> int:\n    return a + 2\n\n\n@workflow\ndef level2(l: typing.List[int]) -> typing.List[int]:\n    return map_task(mappable)(a=l)\n\n\n@task\ndef reduce(l: typing.List[typing.List[int]]) -> typing.List[int]:\n    f = []\n    for i in l:\n        f.extend(i)\n    return f\n\n\n@dynamic\ndef level1(l: typing.List[int], chunk: int) -> typing.List[int]:\n    v = []\n    for i in range(0, len(l), chunk):\n        v.append(level2(l=l[i : i + chunk]))\n    return reduce(l=v)\n\n\n@workflow\ndef multi_wf(l: typing.List[int], chunk: int) -> typing.List[int]:\n    return level1(l=l, chunk=chunk)
```

        report,
        help="Review the report and approve if it looks good",
    )

LANGUAGE: python

@task()
def task_remove_column(input_file: FlyteFile, column_name: str) -> FlyteFile:
    """
    Reads the input file as a DataFrame, removes a specified column, and outputs it as a new file.
    """
    input_file.download()
    df = pd.read_csv(input_file.path)

    # remove column
    if column_name in df.columns:
        df = df.drop(columns=[column_name])

    output_file_path = "data_finished.csv"
    df.to_csv(output_file_path, index=False)

    return FlyteFile(output_file_path)
```

TITLE: Implementing FastAPI Backend Plugin Server
DESCRIPTION: FastAPI server implementation for handling plugin operations including create, poll and delete resources. Defines REST endpoints for plugin management with proper error handling and status codes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/rfc/system/0000-exteranl-plugin-service.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from fastapi import FastAPI
from flytekit.backend.plugins import TaskInfo, IO, PollResultSuccess,
               PollResultFailure, OperationInProgress, PollResult

app = FastAPI()

@app.put("/plugins/v1/{task_type}/{version}")
def create(task_info: TaskInfo) -> ResourceInfo:
    """
    Creates resource.
    
    return job_id, error code, message
    200 Job was created.
    401 The request was unauthorized.
    500 The request was not handled correctly due to a server error.
    """
    return {"job_id": job_id, "error_code": error_code, "message": message}

@app.get("/plugins/v1/{task_type}/{version}")
async def poll(resource_id: int, task_info: TaskInfo, io: IO, resource_info: ResourceInfo) -> PollResult:
    """
    Retrieves resource and returns the current observable status
    
    return job_spec, job_state (succeed, failed, running), error core, message.
    200 Job was retrieved successfully.
    400 The request was malformed. See JSON response for error details.
    401 The request was unauthorized.
    500 The request was not handled correctly due to a server error.
    """
    if resp.state == "success":
       state = succeed
    elif resp.state == "failure":
       state = failed
    elif resp.state == "running":
        state = running
    return {"job_spec": job_spec, "job_state": state, "error_code": error_code, "message": message}

@app.delete("/plugins/v1/{task_type}/{version}")
async def delete_res(resource_id: str):
    """
    Delete the resource
    
    return job_id, error core, message.
    200 Job was deleted successfully.
    400 The request was malformed. See JSON response for error details.
    401 The request was unauthorized.
    500 The request was not handled correctly due to a server error.
    """
    return {"job_id": job_id, "error_code": error_code, "message": message}
```

TITLE: Implementing Input/Output Logging Decorator for Flyte Tasks
DESCRIPTION: This function defines a decorator that logs the input and output details for a decorated Flyte task. It uses functools.wraps to preserve task metadata.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/decorating_tasks.md#2025-04-16_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
def log_io(fn):
    @wraps(fn)
    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
        logger.info(f"Inputs: args={args}, kwargs={kwargs}")
        output = fn(*args, **kwargs)
        logger.info(f"Output: {output}")
        return output
    return wrapper
```

TITLE: Implementing MyDataset Custom Type
DESCRIPTION: Definition of a custom MyDataset class that represents a collection of files on disk, with methods for file operations and path management.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/extending/custom_types.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class MyDataset:
    def __init__(self, path: str):
        self._path = path

    @property
    def path(self) -> str:
        return self._path

    def write(self, file_name: str, contents: str):
        with open(os.path.join(self._path, file_name), "w") as fh:
            fh.write(contents)

    def read(self, file_name: str) -> str:
        with open(os.path.join(self._path, file_name), "r") as fh:
            return fh.read()
```

TITLE: Implementing Simple Conditional Branch in Flyte Workflow
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates a simple conditional branch in a Flyte workflow, choosing between calculating circle circumference or area based on input.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/advanced_composition/conditionals.md#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@task
def calculate_circle_circumference(radius: float) -> float:
    return 2 * 3.14159 * radius

@task
def calculate_circle_area(radius: float) -> float:
    return 3.14159 * radius * radius

@workflow
def shape_properties(radius: float) -> float:
    return (
        conditional("if_fraction")
        .if_((radius >= 0) & (radius <= 1))
        .then(calculate_circle_circumference(radius=radius))
        .else_()  # type: ignore
        .then(calculate_circle_area(radius=radius))
    )
```

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:

@task
def generate_numpy_array() -> np.ndarray:
    """
    Generate a numpy array that will be converted to a parquet file.
    """
    return np.array([i for i in range(100)]).reshape(10, 10)


@task
def consume_numpy_array(array: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """
    Parquet -> NumPy -> computation -> NumPy -> Parquet
    """
    return array + 1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import flytekit
from flytekitplugins.deck.renderer import MarkdownRenderer, BoxRenderer

@task(enable_deck=True)
def iris_data(
    sample_frac: Optional[float] = None,
    random_state: Optional[int] = None,
) -> pd.DataFrame:
    data = px.data.iris()
    if sample_frac is not None:
        data = data.sample(frac=sample_frac, random_state=random_state)

    md_text = (
        "# Iris Dataset\n"
        "This task loads the iris dataset using the  `plotly` package."
    )
    flytekit.current_context().default_deck.append(MarkdownRenderer().to_html(md_text))
    flytekit.Deck("box plot", BoxRenderer("sepal_length").to_html(data))
    return data
```

TITLE: Python script for calculating ellipse area

import os

# Read inputs
with open('/var/inputs/radius1', 'r') as f:
    radius1 = float(f.read().strip())

TITLE: Log Processing and Deck Filtering for Jupyter Notebook
DESCRIPTION: Utility code for capturing and filtering logs to extract deck file paths. This helper code is used to display the generated HTML decks directly in a Jupyter notebook environment.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/flyte_fundamentals/visualizing_task_input_and_output.md#2025-04-16_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# this is an unrendered cell, used to capture the logs in order to render the
# Flyte Decks directly in the docs.
import datetime
import logging
import os
import re
import shutil
from pythonjsonlogger import jsonlogger
from IPython.display import HTML
from pathlib import Path


class DeckFilter(logging.Filter):

    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.formatter = jsonlogger.JsonFormatter(
            fmt="%(asctime)s %(name)s %(levelname)s %(message)s"
        )
        self.logs = []
        self.deck_files = {}

    def filter(self, record):
        patt = "(.+) task creates flyte deck html to (.+/deck.html)"
        msg = record.getMessage()
        matches = re.match(patt, msg)

        if msg == "Connection error. Skip stats collection.":
            return False

        if matches:
            task, filepath = matches.group(1), matches.group(2)
            self.logs.append(self.formatter.format(record))
            self.deck_files[task] = re.sub("^file://", "", filepath)
        return False

def cp_deck(src):
    src = Path(src)
    target = Path.cwd() / "_flyte_decks" / src.parent.name
    target.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
    shutil.copy(src, target)
    return target / "deck.html"


logger = logging.getLogger("flytekit")
logger.setLevel(20)

deck_filter = DeckFilter()
logger.addFilter(deck_filter)
```

TITLE: Configuring ChatGPT Agent in Flyte Core YAML
DESCRIPTION: YAML configuration for enabling the ChatGPT agent in Flyte core. It specifies the agent-service plugin, sets the default agent for ChatGPT tasks, and configures timeouts.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/deployment/agents/chatgpt.rst#2025-04-16_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: yaml
CODE:
```
configmap:
  enabled_plugins:
    # -- Tasks specific configuration [structure](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/flyteorg/flytepropeller/pkg/controller/nodes/task/config#GetConfig)
    tasks:
      # -- Plugins configuration, [structure](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/flyteorg/flytepropeller/pkg/controller/nodes/task/config#TaskPluginConfig)
      task-plugins:
        # -- [Enabled Plugins](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/flyteorg/flyteplugins/go/tasks/config#Config). Enable sagemaker*, athena if you install the backend
        enabled-plugins:
          - container
          - sidecar
          - k8s-array
          - agent-service

          container: container
          sidecar: sidecar
          container_array: k8s-array
          chatgpt: agent-service
    plugins:

        # so we have the option to adjust the timeout setting here.
        defaultAgent:
          timeouts:

TITLE: Configuring imagePullSecrets in Flyte
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates two methods for configuring imagePullSecrets in Flyte: using a Service Account or Custom Pod Template. The code snippet shows the tab-based documentation structure for these configuration options.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/development_lifecycle/private_images.md#2025-04-16_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: rst
CODE:
```
.. tabs::

   .. tab:: Service Account

      You can use the default or new service account for this option:

      1. Add your ``imagePullSecrets`` configuration to the
         `service account <https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-service-account/#add-image-pull-secret-to-service-account>`__.
      2. Use this service account to log into the private registry and pull the image.
      3. When you create a task/workflow execution this service account should
         be specified to access the private image.

   .. tab:: Custom Pod Template

      This option uses a `custom pod template <https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/pull-image-private-registry/>`__
      to create a pod. This template is automatically added to every ``pod`` that
      Flyte creates.

      1. Add your ``imagePullSecrets`` configuration to this custom pod template.
      2. Update `FlytePropeller <https://github.com/flyteorg/flyteplugins/blob/e2971efbefd9126aca0290ddc931663605dec348/go/tasks/pluginmachinery/flytek8s/config/config.go#L157>`__ about the pod created in the previous step.
      3. FlytePropeller adds ``imagePullSecrets``, along with other customization for the pod,
         to the PodSpec, which should look similar to this
         `manifest <https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/pull-image-private-registry/#create-a-pod-that-uses-your-secret>`__.
      4. The pods with their keys can log in and access the images in the private registry.
         Once you set up the token to authenticate with the private registry, you can pull images from them.
```

TITLE: Implementing Human-in-the-loop Workflow
DESCRIPTION: Example of creating a workflow with gate nodes for human interaction, including wait_for_input, approve, and sleep operations. Shows how to implement approval steps and timeouts.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/CHANGELOG/CHANGELOG-v1.3.0.md#2025-04-16_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from flytekit import wait_for_input, approve, sleep

@workflow
def mainwf(a: int):
    x = t1(a=a)
    s1 = wait_for_input("signal-name", timeout=timedelta(hours=1), expected_type=bool)
    s2 = wait_for_input("signal name 2", timeout=timedelta(hours=2), expected_type=int)
    z = t1(a=5)
    zzz = sleep(timedelta(seconds=10))
    y = t2(a=s2)
    q = t2(a=approve(y, "approvalfory", timeout=timedelta(hours=2)))
    x >> s1
    s1 >> z
    z >> zzz
    ...
```

TITLE: Implementing Nested Conditionals in Flyte Workflow
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to nest conditional sections within other conditional sections in a Flyte workflow.

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@workflow
def nested_conditions(radius: float) -> float:
    return (
        conditional("outer")
        .if_((radius >= 0) & (radius <= 1))
        .then(
            conditional("inner")
            .if_(radius < 0.5)
            .then(calculate_circle_circumference(radius=radius))
            .else_()
            .then(calculate_circle_area(radius=radius))
        )
        .else_()
        .then(calculate_circle_area(radius=radius))
    )
```

TITLE: Implementing WaitForObjectStoreFile Task Plugin Class
DESCRIPTION: Complete implementation of the WaitForObjectStoreFile class that extends PythonFunctionTask to create a sensor plugin that waits for files in object storage.
SOURCE: https://github.com/flyteorg/flyte/blob/master/docs/user_guide/extending/user_container_task_plugins.md#2025-04-16_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class WaitForObjectStoreFile(PythonFunctionTask):
    """
    This is a class that demonstrates how to create a task that actually uses the python function
    to execute arbitrary python code before returning something. This can be quite powerful because it
    can do user-defined things without a formal plugin. Obviously more complicated use cases should create
    a new plugin, but in this case we have a simple "wait for file" use case
    """

    def __init__(self, name: str = None, task_config: Optional[Any] = None, task_function: Optional[Callable] = None, **kwargs):
        task_function = task_function or (lambda path: path)
        super(WaitForObjectStoreFile, self).__init__(
            task_type="wait-for-file",
            name=name,
            task_config=task_config,
            task_function=task_function,
            **kwargs,
        )

    def execute(self, **kwargs) -> Any:
        """
        This function is called from the users process. In flyte backward compatibility mode - this is also
        called from the container
        """
        ctx = context_manager.FlyteContext.current_context()
        # Function to check if a given path exists
        def check_file(path: str) -> bool:
            return ctx.file_access.exists(path)

        # Get the path from the kwargs
        p = kwargs["path"]

        # Check if file exists - if not raise an exception which will cause a retry, else return
        if not check_file(p):
            raise Exception(f"File not found {p}!")
        # Return the same path
        return p
```
